item.title: SDS Learning and Development for Community Psychiatric Nurses
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The learning and development programme outline on self-directed support is for Community Psychiatric Nurses and others delivering post-diagnostic support to people with dementia.
What does it do? 

The learning and development programme outline is a design brief for learning and development on self-directed support for Community Psychiatric Nurses and others delivering post-diagnostic support to people with dementia.

How can you use it? 
The learning and development programme outline can be used as a set of recommendations for how a health and social care partnership could design and deliver learning and development on self-directed support for Community Psychiatric Nurses and others delivering post-diagnostic support to people with dementia.
item.dc:creator: Josie Vallely

item.title: Pilotlight Living Well Characters
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Pilotlight Living Well Characters are for anyone supporting learning and development around self-directed support and younger onset dementia.
What does it do? 

The Pilotlight Living Well Characters are fictional characters based on common characteristics of people with younger onset dementia.

How can you use it? 
The Pilotlight Living Well Characters can be used as case studies in learning and development activities. They can be used to design how self-directed support could work for people with younger onset dementia.
item.dc:creator: Josie Vallely

item.title: Getting from hours to outcomes
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The Getting from Hours to Outcomes Learning Materials are for anyone looking to transition from commissioning or delivering care and support by time and task to outcomes led care and support.
What does it do? 

The Getting from Hours to Outcomes Learning Materials explore two support scenarios for the fictional character of Betsy. One scenario asks groups to design support to meet Betsy’s outcomes using a weekly budget and the other scenario asks groups to design support to meet Betsy’s outcomes using an annual budget. When the groups come together they should be able to reflect on the pros and cons of the two scenarios.

How can you use it? 
The Getting from Hours to Outcomes Learning Materials could be used to promote learning within teams of practitioners or individually.
item.dc:creator: Kate Dowling

item.title: SDS and mental health
item.description:
Who is it for? 
The content and methods to deliver SDS learning and development is for SDS leads, mental health team leaders and service managers, learning and development professionals.
What does it do? 

The document provides content and methods for SDS learning and development for mental health practitioners, people eligible for self-directed support due to their mental health problems, family carers, support workers and independent advocates.

How can you use it? 
The content and methods to deliver SDS learning and development can be used as a set of recommendations for how to design and deliver SDS learning and development for mental health practitioners and others.

item.title: SDS and risk and capacity
item.description:
Who is it for?

What does it do? 

The learning and development course outline is a design brief for joint learning and development on SDS and risk and capacity.

How can you use it? 
The learning and development course outline can be used as a set of recommendations for how a local authority could design and deliver learning and development for practitioners and others.
